awd_titl_txt: Expanding the Toolbox for Quantum Control of Atomic Qudits
awd_abstract_narration:
This project uses the hyperfine degrees of freedom of laser cooled cesium atoms as a testbed on which to develop and test new tools for quantum control and measurement.  Qubits and qudits (d-level quantum systems) encoded in atomic ground hyperfine states are especially useful for such work because they provide long coherence times, can be coherently manipulated with radiofrequency and microwave fields, and can be probed weakly or strongly with optical fields. Efforts will be focused on two closely related areas of research. The first concerns control and measurement of quantum systems with complex internal structure, and has as its primary objectives to implement unitary control of qubits and qudits encoded in the 16-dimensional hyperfine ground manifold, to explore methods to prepare arbitrary mixed states and implement completely positive maps, and to improve or develop new protocols for quantum state and process tomography based on weak measurement and augmented by new ideas such as compressed sensing.  The second focus area relates to quantum control on real world platforms, and has as its primary goals to improve and extend tools for robust qudit control in inhomogeneously broadened quantum systems, and to apply these to atoms in optical dipole traps and optical nanofiber surface traps. The research is primarily experimental, but numerical simulation and more formal theoretical study will also be undertaken.

The field of Quantum Information Science (QIS) is motivated by the promise of transformative approaches to computation, communication, and ultra-precise measurement. It has also inspired new ways of thinking about old problems and unresolved issues in physics, and played a role in quantum simulations that study the real-world applicability of idealized theoretical models. QIS is now pursued in many contexts, including nanofabricated condensed matter systems, cold atoms and ions, linear and nonlinear optical systems, and various hybrids thereof. Though details vary with the physics at hand, one of the most fundamental challenges of QIS is universal: one must prepare the relevant quantum system in a well defined initial state, drive it though a complex evolution, and access the final state through measurement. In doing so, many of the tools developed on one platform can be applied to another.  This project will use cold atoms as a testbed for control of quantum systems that have more than two levels.  The resulting toolbox is likely to be useful and perhaps essential in the many implementations where carriers of quantum information have complex internal structure. The project will also contribute to the training of future scientists in the highly interdisciplinary field of QIS.  Students will be involved in all aspects of the project, including education, research, and the dissemination of results.  The project is a cornerstone of the NSF supported Center for Quantum Information and Control, co-located at the University of Arizona College of Optical Science and the University of New Mexico Department of Physics and Astronomy.  Weekly video conferencing, an annual research retreat, and joint participation in conferences will enrich the educational experience and strengthen the connections between junior and senior participants at both institutions.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. The field of Quantum Information Science (QIS) is motivated in part by the promise of transformative approaches to computation, communication and measurement. QIS is pursued on a large variety of physical platforms but the underlying challenge is universal: one must prepare the relevant quantum system in a well defined initial state, drive it through a complex evolution, and access the final state through measurement.  In doing so, many of the tools developed on one platform can be applied to another.  The goal of this project has been to develop a platform independent toolbox for systems that go beyond simple 2-state systems (qubits); such tools are essential in scenarios where the carriers of information are d-dimensional systems (qudits).  The research used as its physical test bed the coupled nuclear and electronic spins of ultracold cesium atoms. This system can be manipulated with radiofrequency and microwave fields and probed through interaction with light. Specific accomplishments include

  • Laboratory demonstration of quantum state control of a 16-level quantum system.  This experiment used computer optimized radiofrequency and microwave fields to drive the quantum system between known, randomly chosen initial and final states.  Average fidelities as high as 99.5% were achieved.  This means that the system ends up in the right state in 995 of 1000 trials on average.
  • Laboratory demonstration of unitary control of a 16-level quantum system. Unitary control of a d-level system requires simultaneous transformation of d orthogonal states and is far more demanding than transforming a single state.  It is the most general kind of control that preserves quantum superpositions and entanglement.  Average fidelities as high as 98.5% were achieved using the same general approach as for state control.
  • First laboratory demonstration of robust unitary control for a d >2 level system.  In robust control one uses computer optimization to find control fields that achieve high fidelity even when unknown perturbations are present.  The approach delivered high fidelities (average of 98.5%) in the presence of a wide range of deliberately applied static and/or time varying perturbations.
  • First laboratory demonstration of addressable unitary control for a d >2 level system. Addressable control is the reverse of robust control: one seeks control fields that implement different transformations according to the value of a perturbation.  The project sucessfully used the light shift from a laser beam to target different transformations on atoms in different regions of space.
  • Comprehensive laboratory tests of strategies for quantum state tomography (QST).  In QST one performs measurements on a quantum system and uses the outcomes to reverse-engineer the state.  QST is a potentially powerful diagnostic tool for quantum information science but its use has been limited by the sheer amount of data that must be collected.  A number of measurement strategies have been developed to make the process more efficient, including some that take advantage of prior information about the state (e. g., that it is close to pure).  The project achieved average QST fidelities as high as 94% for a 16-level system, meaning that a known input state was reconstruct correctly in 94 out of 100 trials.  Clear tradeoffs were identified between efficiency (reconstruction from fewer measurements) and robustness (accurate reconstruction when using imperfect measurements).

Broad impact.  The project has contributed to the knowledge base of quantum information science and to the recruitment and training of future scientists. It has provided dissertation topics and funding for 3 full time students, one of whom will graduate with the PhD in fall 2016 and then take up a Postdoctoral position at the University of Maryland.  The PI’s research group is a cornerstone of the Center for Quantum Information and Control, and partners in regular activities through which the project has impacted a broader community of students, postdocs, faculty and staff at the University of New Mexico, Sandia and Los Alamos National Labs, and other CQuIC partner institutions.
